Award.AwardTitle: Understanding the Failure Mechanisims of Nanoelectrodes in Li-Ion Batteries: Integrating Multiscale Modeling with In-situ Experimental Studies

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this award is to elucidate the mechanisms of electro-chemically driven mechanical degradation in Si/C composite nanoelectrodes through an integrated experimental/computational approach. The nanoelectrodes consist of silicon nanocrystalline droplets deposited on the inner and outer surface of single-walled carbon nanotubes. This research has four tightly-integrated threads: i) develop first-principles based reactive force fields (ReaxFF) for Li-Si-C systems that enable large-scale atomistic simulations with quantum mechanical accuracy, ii) perform atomistic simulations with ReaxFF to extract basic thermodynamic properties of lithiated CNY and silicon nanodroplets as well as the kinetic parameters of lithium insertion, iii) develop an atomistically informed front-tracking finite element method to simulate and understand size-dependent morphological evolution, stress generation, and defect growth in nanoelectodes, and iv) perform in-situ electron microscopy studies of electrochemically driven deformation, defect nucleation, and growth at the nanoscale.

This research will contribute both cutting edge numerical simulations and nanoscale in-situ experiments of the complex, coupled electrochemical-mechanical phenomena that occur in battery electrodes and lead to degradation and ultimately loss of battery capacity. The research is highly interdisciplinary and will involve interactions and visits with Sandia National Laboratories for the participating students; this will expose them to cutting-edge experimental facilities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Electrical energy storage is a key component of the renewables-friendly future power grid with high-energy efficiency, stability, and resilience. Lithium-ion battery (LIB) is currently the best performing battery form. Silicon (Si) has been identified as one of the most promising anode materials for LIBs. However, Si anodes suffer from rapid, irreversible capacity decay and poor due to the Li-ion insertion/extraction induced mechanical degradation. This project aims to develop a fundamental understanding on the degradation mechanisms of Si-based nanoelectrodes in LIBs through integrated multiscale modeling and in-situ transmission electron microscopy.

The research outcomes of this project are of several folds. First, we have established that during the charging and discharging processes of Si anodes, lithiation kinetics (the chemical reaction rate, the lithium diffusivity, and the preferred reaction surface, etc.) and the mechanical stress generated during charging/discharging are strongly coupled. One the one hand, the preferred lithium diffusion channels in Si defines stress profile in the Si anodes and thus the anisotropic deformation morphology as well as the fracture of Si anodes; on the other, the mechanical stress generated inside Si anodes slows down further charging, causing lithiation retardation. Second, to mitigate the chemomechanical degradation of the high-capacity electrodes, we explored three different strategies: using nanostructured materials, surface coating, and porous materials. Our research demonstrated that all these three strategies enhance the electrochemical performance of the high-capacity electrode materials. Third, inspired by the strong coupling between lithiation kinetics and mechanical stress, we developed a device prototype for mechanical energy harvesting. 

The project has resulted in more than 20 journal articles, in prestigious journals, including Nano Letters, ACS Nano, Nature Communications, Nature Nanotechnology, Journal of the Mechanics and Physics of Solids, etc. A provisional patent has been applied for the mechanical energy harvester.

The intellectual merit of the project is of several folds: first, we have developed a robust multiscale modeling framework to predict and analyze the chemomechanical degradation mechanisms of high-energy-density electrode materials; second, we have improved the in-situ TEM technologies for imaging the degradation process in materials with atomic resolution; third, we have developed reactive force fields to understand the atomic-scale bonding structure and stress generation inside the high-energy storage materials. These modeling and experimental tools will benefit research communities to carry battery design steps further.

The broader impact of this project lies in the design of next-generation electrode materials that are not only of high energy density and high power, but also chemomechanically durable. The project has provided excellent opportunities to train undergraduate and graduate students at Penn State. The project has supported two graduate students; both are now graduate students. Two more graduates have been interested in this project and that has led to continuation of the research in the PI’s group. The research results have been incorporated into the two courses that PI teach regularly: Nanobiomechanics and Multiscale modeling. With this project, the PI and the students supported have disseminated their research results in a number of conferences (ASME, SES, MRS, etc.) and universities.
